Greetings.


  My code throws a custom RuntimeException, but I found out that it gets lost by
Eclipse's core platform.  Following is the stack trace I get:

org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.AssertionFailedException: assertion failed:
The application has not been initialized.

	at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.open(Window.java:541)
	at biz.deragon.zarionna.client.Main.main(Main.java:81)

The assertion exception occurs because of another exception of type
RuntimeException with a message like "Model passed is null.  Need a valid
model." that was thrown by my code.  I found out that my exception is handled in
the class InternalPlatform, particularly in the following function:

public static void run(ISafeRunnable code) {
	Assert.isNotNull(code);
	try {
		code.run();
	} catch (Exception e) {
		handleException(code, e);
	} catch (LinkageError e) {
		handleException(code, e);
	}
}

Notice that handleException(code, e) is called when my exception is caught. 
Somewhere further down the stack is an assertion that is made and because it
fails, a new assertion exception is thrown.  The original exception is then lost
and therefore, the user is not made aware of the real problem.

I believe that if the application throws an exception, it must show up on the
console window for the programmer to see.  My workaround when I get this
assertion exception is to set a break point in InternalProceess.Run() just
before the call to handleException() so I can inspect the real exception that
occured and find out what really is wrong with my code.  This happens to me
often and I beleive that I must not be the only developper suffering from this
kind of "exception eating".

From the stack trace, it looks like you're trying to use code from Eclipse
without starting the Eclipse platform. Are you writing a plugin, or just linking
JARs from Eclipse into a stand-alone java program?
I am just linking jars into a standalone appl.

Eclipse platform code is not designed to be run with a stand-alone program.  The
Eclipse platform must be up and running before you can meaningfully use any API.
I suggest you refactor your program as an Eclipse application (see the doc for
more details, the extension point is org.eclipse.core.runtime.application). 
This is fairly easy to do, and then the Eclipse runtime and plug-in registry
will be initialized and our API can be used safely.

Last comment, you wrote:

>I suggest you refactor your program as an Eclipse application 
>(see the doc for more details, the extension point is
>org.eclipse.core.runtime.application)

Mmm... what doc should I look at?  There is a lot of documents, and I search a
few but did not found a "how to create a standalone application" chapter.  I
read the PDE, but I cannot figure out how to convert my project to a plugin and
get the plugin manifest editor showing up.  Care to provide some help?

Documentation for the extension point can be found here:

Platform Plug-in Developer Guide -> Reference -> Extension Points Reference -> 
Platform Runtime -> org.eclipse.core.runtime.applications

The Platform Plug-in Developer Guide also contains more information about 
creating a simple plug-in project.
